bioghist.p: Otto Edwin Albrecht (1988-1984) was a professor and curator of the music library at the University of Pennsylvania. He earned his bachelor's degree from Penn in 1921, and after studying at the University of Copenhagen, he returned to teach French at the University and at the same time completed his master's degree (1925). He earned his doctorate in French from Penn in 1931. He taught French at the University and lectured in the music department. In 1937, Albrecht became curator of the music library. He is the author of A Census of Autograph Music Manuscripts of European Composers in American Libraries (1953). He retired in 1970. The University renamed the music library in his honor, and he continued as the curator there until his death.

scopecontent.p: The collection consists primarily of typed and manuscript notes compiled from New York, Boston, and Philadelphia newspapers from 1800-1840. The notes include listings of musical events, musical societies, publications, teachers, and instrument makers and dealers. Newspapers surveyed include the New York Herald, the Aurora General Advertiser, Poulson's Daily American Advertiser, the Boston Gazette, and the Independent Chronicle. The collection also includes a small amount of correspondence related to Albrecht's work on a census of European music held in collections in the United States, and the building of a music microfilm archive (a project funded by the Oberlaender Trust). There are also music catalogs, publishing announcements, programs, and bulletins.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
